pages.text: Draconichthys elegans was a species of arthrodire placoderm that lived during the Late Devonian (some 383 - 372 million years ago) in what is now the Anti-Atlas Mountains of Morocco. During this time, this part of the world was a shallow, algae-rich sea. Draconichthys could be distinguished from its

closest relatives by its large, pronged gnathal plates (i.e. the bony plates placoderms had instead of true teeth). The sharp, tooth-like appearance of these prongs suggests that this animal was a predator, that used them to hold captured prey still and prevent it from wriggling free.
